comment_text.dn23:1.2: Kumārakassapa was ordained at twenty (Kd 1:75.1.1). He features in the Vammikasutta (MN 23), and his verses are collected in the Theragāthā (Thag 2.41). He was declared the foremost of those with brilliant speech (AN 1.217), apparently on the basis of this discourse. | The Pāyāsisuta is the only major Buddhist text that has a Jain parallel, Paesi-kahāṇayaṁ, a similar dialogue between Paesi and Keśin in Setavyā.
comment_text.dn23:1.4: Pāyāsi was a khattiya yet he receives a brahmadeyya. The sense of brahmadeyya as a donation to brahmins is well attested in inscriptions, so I think this is likely a mistake in the text, rather than evidence that the practice was not for brahmins only.
comment_text.dn23:5.4: This idiom recurs at AN 6.38:1.5 where, as here, it refers to a well-known view and cannot mean that they have never heard of it. There the text and commentary read māhaṁ, which with the aorist is prohibitive not negatory. It is an idiom expressing dislike.
comment_text.dn23:5.11: While the world “down here” is bogged down in its messy and ephemeral issues, the heavenly bodies proceed in their serene, glorious, stately indifference. Ignoring gravity, self-luminous, and apparently eternal, they operate according to what appears to be an entirely different set of rules, a “meta-physics”. What Newton did in physics the Buddha did in spirituality: show that the heavens, despite appearances, operate with the same set of conditioned rules as apply down here.
comment_text.dn23:5.12: Kassapa’s argument here doesn’t directly establish his conclusion. It is possible that gods exist on an entirely separate plane that has nothing to do with kamma and rebirth.
comment_text.dn23:6.18: This is still a major factor in shaping belief. People will reject the opinions of experts and believe people that they know.
comment_text.dn23:6.21: Compare Jaiminīya Brāhmaņa 1.42, where Varuṇa asphyxiated his son Bhṛgu in order to send him on a journey to the “other world”, inducing a near-death experience. Bhṛgu saw men cutting other men to pieces and eating them, and other sights both horrifying and beautiful, all the while wondering if what he saw was real, before his breath was returned to him.
comment_text.dn23:7.10: Follow PTS reading uddassetvā, which at MN 82:11.9 has the sense “visit”.
comment_text.dn23:7.19: Kassapa, however, has not established the existence of an afterlife, he has merely refuted Pāyāsi’s argument. Per Occam’s razor, the burden of proof lies on the one who wishes to establish the existence of the afterlife, not on the one who denies it. His arguments, however, become more persuasive if they are understood as building on the initial agreement on the divinity of the sun and moon. He knows that Pāyāsi accepts some form of other world, even if he says otherwise, so the argument hinges on whether Pāyāsi’s methods are sufficient to disprove the kind of other world that Kassapa proposes, i.e. one driven by kamma.
comment_text.dn23:9.31: Follow PTS reading ubbāhati. Cf. AN 3.93:6.4 for the sense “transport”.
comment_text.dn23:11.10: This recognizes the relativity of time.
comment_text.dn23:11.13: Pāyāsi makes a good point; he only relies on sources that he knows he can trust.
comment_text.dn23:11.41: Kassapa establishes the empirical method by which these truths are known. Science extends knowledge by means of external instruments, while meditation extends the scope of consciousness. A non-scientist cannot understand how a scientist establishes their conclusions, and can only rely on trust in the scientific establishment. Likewise a non-meditator cannot understand the capacity of expanded consciousness.
comment_text.dn23:13.13: The commentary explains opabhoggā (“reward”) as pādaparicārikā (“wife”).
comment_text.dn23:13.27: Prefer Mahāsaṅgīti reading yāva vijāyāmi over PTS yāva jānāmi (“until I know”); it echoes yāva vijāyāmi above. The phrase is not fully coherent, which is understandable given the circumstances.
comment_text.dn23:13.29: “Irrationally” is ayoniso, literally “not sourcewise”. This passage gives a nice real world example of what it means: the means employed are unrelated to the end sought.
comment_text.dn23:14.10: Pāyāsi’s experiments were cruel, but no more so than many recorded in recent history.
comment_text.dn23:14.13: We assume that a soul must be immaterial and invisible, but clearly this was not always the case at the time. From DN 1 we know that there was an almost inexhaustible variety of views about the self or soul.
comment_text.dn23:15.2: This echoes Upaniṣadic discussions of the nature of the dream state and its relation to death. See for example Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.1.18, which says one might become a brahmin or king in a dream.
comment_text.dn23:15.6: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.19 describes the soul returning to the body like a tired hawk returning to the nest.
comment_text.dn23:16.10: Aside from the cruelty, this echoes the dictum attributed to Galileo: “Measure what is measurable, and make measurable what is not so.” Given sufficient precision, this method could be effective in testing for the existence for a physical soul that has mass.
comment_text.dn23:16.13: A dead body will, if anything, weigh less due to excretion and dehydration.
comment_text.dn23:17.5: The misconception that iron is lighter when heated is repeated elsewhere (eg. SN 51.22:4.1). In fact, assuming there are no chemical reactions, it will be very slightly heavier due to relativistic effects, yet less dense and hence more buoyant. These changes are too small to be detected by Pāyāsi’s methods, though.
comment_text.dn23:18.12: The commentary explains āmato as addhamato (“half-dead”).
comment_text.dn23:18.29: At AN 9.37 this rather abrupt insertion more aptly describes a deep meditation.
comment_text.dn23:19.3: Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.8 employs the same metaphor in the search for the soul.
comment_text.dn23:21.3: Such “matted-hair ascetics” are apparently the “forest hermits” (vānaprastha) whose lifestyle Kauṭilya describes as “celibacy, sleeping on the ground, wearing matted hair and antelope skin, offering daily fire sacrifice, bathing, venerating gods, ancestors, and guests, and eating forest produce” (Arthaśāstra 1.3.11, Olivelle’s translation).
comment_text.dn23:22.7: Pāyāsi honestly acknowledges the role of social conformity and shame in shaping views.
comment_text.dn23:23.3: Although this became the first story of the Jātaka collection (Ja 1), here it is not a Jātaka, as it is not framed as a past life of the Buddha.
comment_text.dn23:23.8: While the places are not specified, the journey from “east to west” across desolate lands suggests they may have been venturing from the rich plains of the Ganges west across the Thar Desert of Rajasthan.
comment_text.dn23:23.13: Read with PTS gadrabharathena (“donkey cart”) for bhadrena rathena (“fine cart”).
comment_text.dn23:23.35: The obviously suspicious stranger depicts the genuine dangers of trade in unknown regions, warning the traveler of raiding tribes as well as supernatural creatures.
comment_text.dn23:23.51: Again the criteria that only those who are known may be trusted.
comment_text.dn23:27.4: The ancient Indian game of dice involved casting vibhītaka seeds (also known as “bedda nuts”, from Terminalia bellirica) in a hollow, from which the players would take a handful. A number divisible by four was “perfect” (kaṭa), so the fifth seed meant a “losing” hand (kali; cf. apaṇṇaka in MN 60 and notes).
comment_text.dn23:27.6: Pajohissāmi is related to Sanskrit juhoti, usually used in the sense “to offer as libation”, a meaning accepted by the commentary here. More likely it simply means to “roll out” (like pouring a sacrifice) by analogy.
comment_text.dn23:29.7: Gāmapaṭṭaṁ (variants -padaṁ, -paddhanaṁ, -patthaṁ, pajjaṁ) is explained by the commentary as an abandoned village site.
comment_text.dn23:30.1: Say what you will about Pāyāsi, he had character.
comment_text.dn23:32.2: Bilaṅga is allowed with other medicinal fruits at Kd 6:6.1.4. It is Sanskrit viḍaṅga, identified as embelia ribes or “false black pepper”. | For guḷavālakāni, guḷa is “ball”, vāla is “tail”; compare macchavāḷaka (“fish-tailed”) at Kd 15:29.4.2.
comment_text.dn23:33.1: Divāvihāra is the “day’s meditation”, while divāseyya is “siesta”.

root_text.dn23:8.11: ‘na dānime imamhā ābādhā vuṭṭhahissantī’ti tyāhaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evaṁ vadāmi:
root_text.dn23:8.12: ‘santi kho, bho, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā evaṁvādino evaṁdiṭṭhino:
root_text.dn23:8.13: “ye te pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā samphappalāpā paṭiviratā anabhijjhālū abyāpannacittā sammādiṭṭhī te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjantī”ti.
root_text.dn23:8.14: Bhavanto kho pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā samphappalāpā paṭiviratā anabhijjhālū abyāpannacittā sammādiṭṭhī.
root_text.dn23:8.15: Sace tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ saccaṁ vacanaṁ, bhavanto kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjissanti.
root_text.dn23:8.16: Sace, bho, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjeyyātha, yena me āgantvā āroceyyātha:
root_text.dn23:8.17: “itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”ti.
root_text.dn23:8.18: Bhavanto kho pana me saddhāyikā paccayikā, yaṁ bhavantehi diṭṭhaṁ, yathā sāmaṁ diṭṭhaṁ evametaṁ bhavissatī’ti.
root_text.dn23:8.19: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā neva āgantvā ārocenti, na pana dūtaṁ pahiṇanti.
root_text.dn23:8.20: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn23:8.21: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:9.2: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
root_text.dn23:9.3: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, puriso gūthakūpe sasīsakaṁ nimuggo assa.
root_text.dn23:9.5: ‘tena hi, bho, taṁ purisaṁ tamhā gūthakūpā uddharathā’ti.
root_text.dn23:9.6: Te ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ tamhā gūthakūpā uddhareyyuṁ.
root_text.dn23:9.8: ‘tena hi, bho, tassa purisassa kāyā veḷupesikāhi gūthaṁ sunimmajjitaṁ nimmajjathā’ti.
root_text.dn23:9.9: Te ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā tassa purisassa kāyā veḷupesikāhi gūthaṁ sunimmajjitaṁ nimmajjeyyuṁ.
root_text.dn23:9.11: ‘tena hi, bho, tassa purisassa kāyaṁ paṇḍumattikāya tikkhattuṁ subbaṭṭitaṁ ubbaṭṭethā’ti.
root_text.dn23:9.12: Te tassa purisassa kāyaṁ paṇḍumattikāya tikkhattuṁ subbaṭṭitaṁ ubbaṭṭeyyuṁ.
root_text.dn23:9.14: ‘tena hi, bho, taṁ purisaṁ telena abbhañjitvā sukhumena cuṇṇena tikkhattuṁ suppadhotaṁ karothā’ti.
root_text.dn23:9.15: Te taṁ purisaṁ telena abbhañjitvā sukhumena cuṇṇena tikkhattuṁ suppadhotaṁ kareyyuṁ.
root_text.dn23:9.17: ‘tena hi, bho, tassa purisassa kesamassuṁ kappethā’ti.
root_text.dn23:9.20: ‘tena hi, bho, tassa purisassa mahagghañca mālaṁ mahagghañca vilepanaṁ mahagghāni ca vatthāni upaharathā’ti.
root_text.dn23:9.21: Te tassa purisassa mahagghañca mālaṁ mahagghañca vilepanaṁ mahagghāni ca vatthāni upahareyyuṁ.
root_text.dn23:9.23: ‘tena hi, bho, taṁ purisaṁ pāsādaṁ āropetvā pañcakāmaguṇāni upaṭṭhāpethā’ti.
root_text.dn23:9.24: Te taṁ purisaṁ pāsādaṁ āropetvā pañcakāmaguṇāni upaṭṭhāpeyyuṁ.
root_text.dn23:9.26: api nu tassa purisassa sunhātassa suvilittassa sukappitakesamassussa āmukkamālābharaṇassa odātavatthavasanassa uparipāsādavaragatassa pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitassa samaṅgībhūtassa paricārayamānassa punadeva tasmiṁ gūthakūpe nimujjitukāmatā assā”ti?
root_text.dn23:9.29: “Asuci, bho kassapa, gūthakūpo asuci ceva asucisaṅkhāto ca duggandho ca duggandhasaṅkhāto ca jeguccho ca jegucchasaṅkhāto ca paṭikūlo ca paṭikūlasaṅkhāto cā”ti.
root_text.dn23:9.30: “Evameva kho, rājañña, manussā devānaṁ asucī ceva asucisaṅkhātā ca, duggandhā ca duggandhasaṅkhātā ca, jegucchā ca jegucchasaṅkhātā ca, paṭikūlā ca paṭikūlasaṅkhātā ca.
root_text.dn23:9.31: Yojanasataṁ kho, rājañña, manussagandho deve ubbādhati.
root_text.dn23:9.32: Kiṁ pana te mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā pisuṇāya vācāya paṭiviratā pharusāya vācāya paṭiviratā samphappalāpā paṭiviratā anabhijjhālū abyāpannacittā sammādiṭṭhī, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā te āgantvā ārocessanti:
root_text.dn23:9.33: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’ti?
root_text.dn23:9.34: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
root_text.dn23:9.35: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.

root_text.dn23:10.13: Sace tesaṁ bhavataṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ saccaṁ vacanaṁ, bhavanto kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjissanti, devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ.

root_text.dn23:10.16: Bhavanto kho pana me saddhāyikā paccayikā, yaṁ bhavantehi diṭṭhaṁ, yathā sāmaṁ diṭṭhaṁ evametaṁ bhavissatī’ti.
root_text.dn23:10.17: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā neva āgantvā ārocenti, na pana dūtaṁ pahiṇanti.

root_text.dn23:11.1: “Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi; yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
root_text.dn23:11.2: Yaṁ kho pana, rājañña, mānussakaṁ vassasataṁ, devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ eso eko rattindivo, tāya rattiyā tiṁsarattiyo māso, tena māsena dvādasamāsiyo saṁvaccharo, tena saṁvaccharena dibbaṁ vassasahassaṁ devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ āyuppamāṇaṁ.
root_text.dn23:11.3: Ye te mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā adinnādānā paṭiviratā kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā musāvādā paṭiviratā surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sahabyataṁ.
root_text.dn23:11.5: ‘yāva mayaṁ dve vā tīṇi vā rattindivā dibbehi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārema, atha mayaṁ pāyāsissa rājaññassa gantvā āroceyyāma:
root_text.dn23:11.6: “itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”ti.
root_text.dn23:11.8: itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti?
root_text.dn23:11.10: Api hi mayaṁ, bho kassapa, ciraṁ kālaṅkatāpi bhaveyyāma.
root_text.dn23:11.12: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā ‘evaṁdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā.
root_text.dn23:11.14: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā ‘evaṁdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā”ti.
root_text.dn23:11.16: “Seyyathāpi, rājañña, jaccandho puriso na passeyya kaṇha—sukkāni rūpāni, na passeyya nīlakāni rūpāni, na passeyya pītakāni rūpāni, na passeyya lohitakāni rūpāni, na passeyya mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, na passeyya samavisamaṁ, na passeyya tārakāni rūpāni, na passeyya candimasūriye.
root_text.dn23:11.18: ‘natthi kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, natthi kaṇhasukkānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
root_text.dn23:11.19: Natthi nīlakāni rūpāni, natthi nīlakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
root_text.dn23:11.20: Natthi pītakāni rūpāni, natthi pītakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
root_text.dn23:11.21: Natthi lohitakāni rūpāni, natthi lohitakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
root_text.dn23:11.22: Natthi mañjiṭṭhakāni rūpāni, natthi mañjiṭṭhakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
root_text.dn23:11.24: Natthi tārakāni rūpāni, natthi tārakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
root_text.dn23:11.26: Ahametaṁ na jānāmi, ahametaṁ na passāmi, tasmā taṁ natthī’ti.
root_text.dn23:11.27: Sammā nu kho so, rājañña, vadamāno vadeyyā”ti?
root_text.dn23:11.29: Atthi kaṇhasukkāni rūpāni, atthi kaṇhasukkānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
root_text.dn23:11.30: Atthi nīlakāni rūpāni, atthi nīlakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī …pe…
root_text.dn23:11.32: Atthi tārakāni rūpāni, atthi tārakānaṁ rūpānaṁ dassāvī.
root_text.dn23:11.34: ‘Ahametaṁ na jānāmi, ahametaṁ na passāmi, tasmā taṁ natthī’ti.
root_text.dn23:11.35: Na hi so, bho kassapa, sammā vadamāno vadeyyā”ti.
root_text.dn23:11.36: “Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, jaccandhūpamo maññe paṭibhāsi yaṁ maṁ tvaṁ evaṁ vadesi.
root_text.dn23:11.38: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā, ‘evaṁdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā?
root_text.dn23:11.40: ‘atthi devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā ‘evaṁdīghāyukā devā tāvatiṁsā’ti vā”ti.
root_text.dn23:11.41: “Na kho, rājañña, evaṁ paro loko daṭṭhabbo, yathā tvaṁ maññasi iminā maṁsacakkhunā.
root_text.dn23:11.42: Ye kho te, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā araññavanapatthāni pantāni senāsanāni paṭisevanti, te tattha appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharantā dibbacakkhuṁ visodhenti.
root_text.dn23:11.43: Te dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena imañceva lokaṁ passanti parañca satte ca opapātike.
root_text.dn23:11.44: Evañca kho, rājañña, paro loko daṭṭhabbo;
root_text.dn23:11.45: na tveva yathā tvaṁ maññasi iminā maṁsacakkhunā.
root_text.dn23:11.46: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
root_text.dn23:11.47: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:12.1: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
root_text.dn23:12.2: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:12.6: “Idhāhaṁ, bho kassapa, passāmi samaṇabrāhmaṇe sīlavante kalyāṇadhamme jīvitukāme amaritukāme sukhakāme dukkhapaṭikūle.
root_text.dn23:12.7: Tassa mayhaṁ, bho kassapa, evaṁ hoti—
root_text.dn23:12.8: sace kho ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā evaṁ jāneyyuṁ:
root_text.dn23:12.10: Idānime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā visaṁ vā khādeyyuṁ, satthaṁ vā āhareyyuṁ, ubbandhitvā vā kālaṁ kareyyuṁ, papāte vā papateyyuṁ.
root_text.dn23:12.11: Yasmā ca kho ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā na evaṁ jānanti:
root_text.dn23:12.12: ‘ito no matānaṁ seyyo bhavissatī’ti, tasmā ime bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā jīvitukāmā amaritukāmā sukhakāmā dukkhapaṭikūlā attānaṁ na mārenti.
root_text.dn23:12.13: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn23:12.14: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:13.2: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
root_text.dn23:13.3: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññatarassa brāhmaṇassa dve pajāpatiyo ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn23:13.4: Ekissā putto ahosi dasavassuddesiko vā dvādasavassuddesiko vā, ekā gabbhinī upavijaññā.
root_text.dn23:13.6: Atha kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn23:13.7: ‘yamidaṁ, bhoti, dhanaṁ vā dhaññaṁ vā rajataṁ vā jātarūpaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ mayhaṁ;
root_text.dn23:13.10: Evaṁ vutte, sā brāhmaṇī taṁ māṇavakaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn23:13.12: Sace kumārako bhavissati, tassapi ekadeso bhavissati;
root_text.dn23:13.13: sace kumārikā bhavissati, sāpi te opabhoggā bhavissatī’ti.
root_text.dn23:13.14: Dutiyampi kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn23:13.15: ‘yamidaṁ, bhoti, dhanaṁ vā dhaññaṁ vā rajataṁ vā jātarūpaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ mayhaṁ;
root_text.dn23:13.18: Dutiyampi kho sā brāhmaṇī taṁ māṇavakaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn23:13.20: Sace kumārako bhavissati, tassapi ekadeso bhavissati;
root_text.dn23:13.21: sace kumārikā bhavissati sāpi te opabhoggā bhavissatī’ti.
root_text.dn23:13.22: Tatiyampi kho so māṇavako mātusapattiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn23:13.23: ‘yamidaṁ, bhoti, dhanaṁ vā dhaññaṁ vā rajataṁ vā jātarūpaṁ vā, sabbaṁ taṁ mayhaṁ;
root_text.dn23:13.26: Atha kho sā brāhmaṇī satthaṁ gahetvā ovarakaṁ pavisitvā udaraṁ opādesi:
root_text.dn23:13.27: ‘yāva vijāyāmi yadi vā kumārako yadi vā kumārikā’ti.
root_text.dn23:13.28: Sā attānañceva jīvitañca gabbhañca sāpateyyañca vināsesi.
root_text.dn23:13.29: Yathā taṁ bālā abyattā anayabyasanaṁ āpannā ayoniso dāyajjaṁ gavesantī, evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, bālo abyatto anayabyasanaṁ āpajjissasi ayoniso paralokaṁ gavesanto;
root_text.dn23:13.30: seyyathāpi sā brāhmaṇī bālā abyattā anayabyasanaṁ āpannā ayoniso dāyajjaṁ gavesantī.
root_text.dn23:13.31: Na kho, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā apakkaṁ paripācenti;
root_text.dn23:13.33: Paṇḍitānaṁ attho hi, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ sīlavantānaṁ kalyāṇadhammānaṁ jīvitena.
root_text.dn23:13.34: Yathā yathā kho, rājañña, samaṇabrāhmaṇā sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā ciraṁ dīghamaddhānaṁ tiṭṭhanti tathā tathā bahuṁ puññaṁ pasavanti, bahujanahitāya ca paṭipajjanti bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
root_text.dn23:13.35: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
root_text.dn23:13.36: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:14.1: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
root_text.dn23:14.2: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:14.6: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
root_text.dn23:14.8: imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
root_text.dn23:14.10: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ jīvantaṁyeva kumbhiyā pakkhipitvā mukhaṁ pidahitvā allena cammena onandhitvā allāya mattikāya bahalāvalepanaṁ karitvā uddhanaṁ āropetvā aggiṁ dethā’ti.
root_text.dn23:14.11: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ jīvantaṁyeva kumbhiyā pakkhipitvā mukhaṁ pidahitvā allena cammena onandhitvā allāya mattikāya bahalāvalepanaṁ karitvā uddhanaṁ āropetvā aggiṁ denti.
root_text.dn23:14.12: Yadā mayaṁ jānāma ‘kālaṅkato so puriso’ti, atha naṁ kumbhiṁ oropetvā ubbhinditvā mukhaṁ vivaritvā saṇikaṁ nillokema:
root_text.dn23:14.15: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn23:14.16: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:15.1: “Tena hi, rājañña, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi, yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
root_text.dn23:15.2: Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, rājañña, divā seyyaṁ upagato supinakaṁ passitā ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan”ti?
root_text.dn23:15.3: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, bho kassapa, divāseyyaṁ upagato supinakaṁ passitā ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan”ti.
root_text.dn23:15.4: “Rakkhanti taṁ tamhi samaye khujjāpi vāmanakāpi velāsikāpi komārikāpī”ti?
root_text.dn23:15.5: “Evaṁ, bho kassapa, rakkhanti maṁ tamhi samaye khujjāpi vāmanakāpi velāsikāpi komārikāpī”ti.
root_text.dn23:15.6: “Api nu tā tuyhaṁ jīvaṁ passanti pavisantaṁ vā nikkhamantaṁ vā”ti?
root_text.dn23:15.8: “Tā hi nāma, rājañña, tuyhaṁ jīvantassa jīvantiyo jīvaṁ na passissanti pavisantaṁ vā nikkhamantaṁ vā.
root_text.dn23:15.9: Kiṁ pana tvaṁ kālaṅkatassa jīvaṁ passissasi pavisantaṁ vā nikkhamantaṁ vā.
root_text.dn23:15.10: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
root_text.dn23:15.11: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:16.1: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
root_text.dn23:16.2: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:16.6: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
root_text.dn23:16.8: imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
root_text.dn23:16.10: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ jīvantaṁyeva tulāya tuletvā jiyāya anassāsakaṁ māretvā punadeva tulāya tulethā’ti.
root_text.dn23:16.11: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ jīvantaṁyeva tulāya tuletvā jiyāya anassāsakaṁ māretvā punadeva tulāya tulenti.
root_text.dn23:16.12: Yadā so jīvati, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
root_text.dn23:16.13: Yadā pana so kālaṅkato hoti tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro ca.
root_text.dn23:16.14: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn23:16.15: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:17.2: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
root_text.dn23:17.3: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, puriso divasaṁ santattaṁ ayoguḷaṁ ādittaṁ sampajjalitaṁ sajotibhūtaṁ tulāya tuleyya.
root_text.dn23:17.4: Tamenaṁ aparena samayena sītaṁ nibbutaṁ tulāya tuleyya.
root_text.dn23:17.5: Kadā nu kho so ayoguḷo lahutaro vā hoti mudutaro vā kammaññataro vā, yadā vā āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto, yadā vā sīto nibbuto”ti?
root_text.dn23:17.6: “Yadā so, bho kassapa, ayoguḷo tejosahagato ca hoti vāyosahagato ca āditto sampajjalito sajotibhūto, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
root_text.dn23:17.7: Yadā pana so ayoguḷo neva tejosahagato hoti na vāyosahagato sīto nibbuto, tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro cā”ti.
root_text.dn23:17.8: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yadāyaṁ kāyo āyusahagato ca hoti usmāsahagato ca viññāṇasahagato ca, tadā lahutaro ca hoti mudutaro ca kammaññataro ca.
root_text.dn23:17.9: Yadā panāyaṁ kāyo neva āyusahagato hoti na usmāsahagato na viññāṇasahagato tadā garutaro ca hoti patthinnataro ca akammaññataro ca.
root_text.dn23:17.10: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
root_text.dn23:17.11: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:18.1: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
root_text.dn23:18.2: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:18.6: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
root_text.dn23:18.8: imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
root_text.dn23:18.10: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ anupahacca chaviñca cammañca maṁsañca nhāruñca aṭṭhiñca aṭṭhimiñjañca jīvitā voropetha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn23:18.11: Te me ‘sādhū’ti paṭissutvā taṁ purisaṁ anupahacca chaviñca …pe… jīvitā voropenti.
root_text.dn23:18.12: Yadā so āmato hoti, tyāhaṁ evaṁ vadāmi:
root_text.dn23:18.13: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ uttānaṁ nipātetha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn23:18.17: ‘tena hi, bho, imaṁ purisaṁ avakujjaṁ nipātetha …
root_text.dn23:18.26: odhunātha sandhunātha niddhunātha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ nikkhamantaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn23:18.27: Te taṁ purisaṁ odhunanti sandhunanti niddhunanti.
root_text.dn23:18.29: Tassa tadeva cakkhu hoti te rūpā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.dn23:18.30: Tadeva sotaṁ hoti te saddā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.dn23:18.31: Tadeva ghānaṁ hoti te gandhā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.dn23:18.32: Sāva jivhā hoti te rasā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.dn23:18.33: Sveva kāyo hoti te phoṭṭhabbā, tañcāyatanaṁ nappaṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.dn23:18.34: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn23:18.35: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:19.2: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
root_text.dn23:19.3: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro saṅkhadhamo saṅkhaṁ ādāya paccantimaṁ janapadaṁ agamāsi.
root_text.dn23:19.4: So yena aññataro gāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā majjhe gāmassa ṭhito tikkhattuṁ saṅkhaṁ upalāpetvā saṅkhaṁ bhūmiyaṁ nikkhipitvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.dn23:19.5: Atha kho, rājañña, tesaṁ paccantajanapadānaṁ manussānaṁ etadahosi:
root_text.dn23:19.6: ‘ambho kassa nu kho eso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
root_text.dn23:19.8: ‘ambho, kassa nu kho eso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
root_text.dn23:19.9: ‘Eso kho, bho, saṅkho nāma yasseso saddo evaṁrajanīyo evaṅkamanīyo evaṁmadanīyo evambandhanīyo evaṁmucchanīyo’ti.
root_text.dn23:19.13: Te taṁ saṅkhaṁ avakujjaṁ nipātesuṁ, passena nipātesuṁ, dutiyena passena nipātesuṁ, uddhaṁ ṭhapesuṁ, omuddhakaṁ ṭhapesuṁ, pāṇinā ākoṭesuṁ, leḍḍunā ākoṭesuṁ, daṇḍena ākoṭesuṁ, satthena ākoṭesuṁ, odhuniṁsu sandhuniṁsu niddhuniṁsu:
root_text.dn23:19.16: Atha kho, rājañña, tassa saṅkhadhamassa etadahosi:
root_text.dn23:19.17: ‘yāva bālā ime paccantajanapadā manussā, kathañhi nāma ayoniso saṅkhasaddaṁ gavesissantī’ti.
root_text.dn23:19.18: Tesaṁ pekkhamānānaṁ saṅkhaṁ gahetvā tikkhattuṁ saṅkhaṁ upalāpetvā saṅkhaṁ ādāya pakkāmi.
root_text.dn23:19.19: Atha kho, rājañña, tesaṁ paccantajanapadānaṁ manussānaṁ etadahosi:
root_text.dn23:19.20: ‘yadā kira, bho, ayaṁ saṅkho nāma purisasahagato ca hoti vāyāmasahagato ca vāyusahagato ca, tadāyaṁ saṅkho saddaṁ karoti, yadā panāyaṁ saṅkho neva purisasahagato hoti na vāyāmasahagato na vāyusahagato, nāyaṁ saṅkho saddaṁ karotī’ti.
root_text.dn23:19.21: Evameva kho, rājañña, yadāyaṁ kāyo āyusahagato ca hoti usmāsahagato ca viññāṇasahagato ca, tadā abhikkamatipi paṭikkamatipi tiṭṭhatipi nisīdatipi seyyampi kappeti, cakkhunāpi rūpaṁ passati, sotenapi saddaṁ suṇāti, ghānenapi gandhaṁ ghāyati, jivhāyapi rasaṁ sāyati, kāyenapi phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusati, manasāpi dhammaṁ vijānāti.
root_text.dn23:19.22: Yadā panāyaṁ kāyo neva āyusahagato hoti, na usmāsahagato, na viññāṇasahagato, tadā neva abhikkamati na paṭikkamati na tiṭṭhati na nisīdati na seyyaṁ kappeti, cakkhunāpi rūpaṁ na passati, sotenapi saddaṁ na suṇāti, ghānenapi gandhaṁ na ghāyati, jivhāyapi rasaṁ na sāyati, kāyenapi phoṭṭhabbaṁ na phusati, manasāpi dhammaṁ na vijānāti.
root_text.dn23:19.23: Imināpi kho te, rājañña, pariyāyena evaṁ hotu:
root_text.dn23:19.24: ‘itipi atthi paro loko, atthi sattā opapātikā, atthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:20.1: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho evaṁ me ettha hoti:
root_text.dn23:20.2: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:20.6: “Idha me, bho kassapa, purisā coraṁ āgucāriṁ gahetvā dassenti:
root_text.dn23:20.8: imassa yaṁ icchasi, taṁ daṇḍaṁ paṇehī’ti.
root_text.dn23:20.10: ‘tena hi, bho, imassa purisassa chaviṁ chindatha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn23:20.14: ‘tena hi, bho, imassa purisassa cammaṁ chindatha, maṁsaṁ chindatha, nhāruṁ chindatha, aṭṭhiṁ chindatha, aṭṭhimiñjaṁ chindatha, appeva nāmassa jīvaṁ passeyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn23:20.15: Te tassa purisassa aṭṭhimiñjaṁ chindanti, nevassa mayaṁ jīvaṁ passeyyāma.
root_text.dn23:20.16: Ayampi kho, bho kassapa, pariyāyo, yena me pariyāyena evaṁ hoti:
root_text.dn23:20.17: ‘itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko’”ti.
root_text.dn23:21.2: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
root_text.dn23:21.3: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro aggiko jaṭilo araññāyatane paṇṇakuṭiyā sammati.
root_text.dn23:21.4: Atha kho, rājañña, aññataro janapade sattho vuṭṭhāsi.
root_text.dn23:21.5: Atha kho so sattho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa assamassa sāmantā ekarattiṁ vasitvā pakkāmi.
root_text.dn23:21.6: Atha kho, rājañña, tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa etadahosi:
root_text.dn23:21.7: ‘yannūnāhaṁ yena so satthavāso tenupasaṅkameyyaṁ, appeva nāmettha kiñci upakaraṇaṁ adhigaccheyyan’ti.
root_text.dn23:21.8: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo kālasseva vuṭṭhāya yena so satthavāso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā addasa tasmiṁ satthavāse daharaṁ kumāraṁ mandaṁ uttānaseyyakaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.
root_text.dn23:21.10: ‘na kho me taṁ patirūpaṁ yaṁ me pekkhamānassa manussabhūto kālaṅkareyya;
root_text.dn23:21.11: yannūnāhaṁ imaṁ dārakaṁ assamaṁ netvā āpādeyyaṁ poseyyaṁ vaḍḍheyyan’ti.
root_text.dn23:21.12: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṁ dārakaṁ assamaṁ netvā āpādesi posesi vaḍḍhesi.
root_text.dn23:21.13: Yadā so dārako dasavassuddesiko vā hoti dvādasavassuddesiko vā, atha kho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa janapade kañcideva karaṇīyaṁ uppajji.
root_text.dn23:21.14: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṁ dārakaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn23:21.18: Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṁ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṁ araṇisahitaṁ, aggiṁ nibbattetvā aggiṁ paricareyyāsī’ti.
root_text.dn23:21.19: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo taṁ dārakaṁ evaṁ anusāsitvā janapadaṁ agamāsi.
root_text.dn23:21.25: Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṁ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṁ araṇisahitaṁ, aggiṁ nibbattetvā aggiṁ paricareyyāsī”ti.
root_text.dn23:21.27: Atha kho so dārako araṇisahitaṁ vāsiyā tacchi:
root_text.dn23:21.30: Araṇisahitaṁ dvidhā phālesi, tidhā phālesi, catudhā phālesi, pañcadhā phālesi, dasadhā phālesi, satadhā phālesi, sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ akāsi, sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ karitvā udukkhale koṭṭesi, udukkhale koṭṭetvā mahāvāte opuni:
root_text.dn23:21.33: Atha kho so aggiko jaṭilo janapade taṁ karaṇīyaṁ tīretvā yena sako assamo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā taṁ dārakaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn23:21.37: “pitā kho maṁ evaṁ avaca aggiṁ, tāta, paricareyyāsi.
root_text.dn23:21.38: Mā ca te, tāta, aggi nibbāyi.
root_text.dn23:21.39: Sace ca te aggi nibbāyeyya, ayaṁ vāsī imāni kaṭṭhāni idaṁ araṇisahitaṁ, aggiṁ nibbattetvā aggiṁ paricareyyāsīti.
root_text.dn23:21.41: Atha khvāhaṁ, tāta, araṇisahitaṁ vāsiyā tacchiṁ:
root_text.dn23:21.44: Araṇisahitaṁ dvidhā phālesiṁ, tidhā phālesiṁ, catudhā phālesiṁ, pañcadhā phālesiṁ, dasadhā phālesiṁ, satadhā phālesiṁ, sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ akāsiṁ, sakalikaṁ sakalikaṁ karitvā udukkhale koṭṭesiṁ, udukkhale koṭṭetvā mahāvāte opuniṁ:
root_text.dn23:21.47: Atha kho tassa aggikassa jaṭilassa etadahosi:
root_text.dn23:21.48: ‘yāva bālo ayaṁ dārako abyatto, kathañhi nāma ayoniso aggiṁ gavesissatī’ti.
root_text.dn23:21.49: Tassa pekkhamānassa araṇisahitaṁ gahetvā aggiṁ nibbattetvā taṁ dārakaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn23:21.51: Na tveva yathā tvaṁ bālo abyatto ayoniso aggiṁ gavesī’ti.
root_text.dn23:21.52: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, bālo abyatto ayoniso paralokaṁ gavesissasi.
root_text.dn23:21.53: Paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ; paṭinissajjetaṁ, rājañña, pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ.
root_text.dn23:21.54: Mā te ahosi dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
root_text.dn23:22.1: “Kiñcāpi bhavaṁ kassapo evamāha, atha kho nevāhaṁ sakkomi idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjituṁ.
root_text.dn23:22.2: Rājāpi maṁ pasenadi kosalo jānāti tirorājānopi:
root_text.dn23:22.4: “itipi natthi paro loko, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko”’ti.
root_text.dn23:22.5: Sacāhaṁ, bho kassapa, idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:
root_text.dn23:22.7: Kopenapi naṁ harissāmi, makkhenapi naṁ harissāmi, palāsenapi naṁ harissāmī”ti.
root_text.dn23:23.2: Upamāya m’idhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
root_text.dn23:23.3: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, mahāsakaṭasattho sakaṭasahassaṁ puratthimā janapadā pacchimaṁ janapadaṁ agamāsi.
root_text.dn23:23.4: So yena yena gacchi, khippaṁyeva pariyādiyati tiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ haritakapaṇṇaṁ.
root_text.dn23:23.5: Tasmiṁ kho pana satthe dve satthavāhā ahesuṁ eko pañcannaṁ sakaṭasatānaṁ, eko pañcannaṁ sakaṭasatānaṁ.
root_text.dn23:23.8: te mayaṁ yena yena gacchāma, khippameva pariyādiyati tiṇakaṭṭhodakaṁ haritakapaṇṇaṁ.
root_text.dn23:23.9: Yannūna mayaṁ imaṁ satthaṁ dvidhā vibhajeyyāma—
root_text.dn23:23.10: ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni ekato pañca sakaṭasatānī’ti.
root_text.dn23:23.11: Te taṁ satthaṁ dvidhā vibhajiṁsu ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni, ekato pañca sakaṭasatāni.
root_text.dn23:23.12: Eko satthavāho bahuṁ tiṇañca kaṭṭhañca udakañca āropetvā satthaṁ payāpesi.

root_text.dn23:23.65: ‘ayaṁ kho, bho, sattho anayabyasanaṁ āpanno, yathā taṁ tena bālena satthavāhena pariṇāyakena.
root_text.dn23:23.66: Tena hi, bho, yānamhākaṁ satthe appasārāni paṇiyāni, tāni chaḍḍetvā, yāni imasmiṁ satthe mahāsārāni paṇiyāni, tāni ādiyathā’ti.
root_text.dn23:23.67: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho te satthikā tassa satthavāhassa paṭissutvā yāni sakasmiṁ satthe appasārāni paṇiyāni, tāni chaḍḍetvā yāni tasmiṁ satthe mahāsārāni paṇiyāni, tāni ādiyitvā sotthinā taṁ kantāraṁ nitthariṁsu, yathā taṁ paṇḍitena satthavāhena pariṇāyakena.
root_text.dn23:23.68: Evameva kho tvaṁ, rājañña, bālo abyatto anayabyasanaṁ āpajjissasi ayoniso paralokaṁ gavesanto, seyyathāpi so purimo satthavāho.

root_text.dn23:24.4: Sacāhaṁ, bho kassapa, idaṁ pāpakaṁ diṭṭhigataṁ paṭinissajjissāmi, bhavissanti me vattāro:

root_text.dn23:25.3: Bhūtapubbaṁ, rājañña, aññataro sūkaraposako puriso sakamhā gāmā aññaṁ gāmaṁ agamāsi.
root_text.dn23:25.6: ‘ayaṁ kho pahūto sukkhagūtho chaḍḍito, mama ca sūkarabhattaṁ;
root_text.dn23:25.8: So uttarāsaṅgaṁ pattharitvā pahūtaṁ sukkhagūthaṁ ākiritvā bhaṇḍikaṁ bandhitvā sīse ubbāhetvā agamāsi.
root_text.dn23:25.10: So uggharantaṁ paggharantaṁ yāva agganakhā gūthena makkhito gūthabhāraṁ ādāya agamāsi.
root_text.dn23:25.12: ‘kacci no tvaṁ, bhaṇe, ummatto, kacci viceto, kathañhi nāma uggharantaṁ paggharantaṁ yāva agganakhā gūthena makkhito gūthabhāraṁ harissasī’ti.
root_text.dn23:25.13: ‘Tumhe khvettha, bhaṇe, ummattā, tumhe vicetā, tathā hi pana me sūkarabhattan’ti.

root_text.dn23:29.7: Te yena so janapado, yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu, tattha addasaṁsu pahūtaṁ sāṇaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn23:29.8: ‘idaṁ kho, samma, pahūtaṁ sāṇaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ bandha, ahañca sāṇabhāraṁ bandhissāmi, ubho sāṇabhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
root_text.dn23:29.9: ‘Evaṁ, sammā’ti kho sahāyako sahāyakassa paṭissutvā sāṇabhāraṁ bandhitvā te ubho sāṇabhāraṁ ādāya yena aññataraṁ gāmapaṭṭaṁ tenupasaṅkamiṁsu.
root_text.dn23:29.10: Tattha addasaṁsu pahūtaṁ sāṇasuttaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ, disvā sahāyako sahāyakaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn23:29.11: ‘yassa kho, samma, atthāya iccheyyāma sāṇaṁ, idaṁ pahūtaṁ sāṇasuttaṁ chaḍḍitaṁ.
root_text.dn23:29.12: Tena hi, samma, tvañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍehi, ahañca sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍessāmi, ubho sāṇasuttabhāraṁ ādāya gamissāmā’ti.
root_text.dn23:29.13: ‘Ayaṁ kho me, samma, sāṇabhāro dūrābhato ca susannaddho ca, alaṁ me, tvaṁ pajānāhī’ti.
root_text.dn23:29.14: Atha kho so sahāyako sāṇabhāraṁ chaḍḍetvā sāṇasuttabhāraṁ ādiyi.

root_text.dn23:30.1: “Purimeneva ahaṁ opammena bhoto kassapassa attamano abhiraddho.
root_text.dn23:30.2: Api cāhaṁ imāni vicitrāni pañhāpaṭibhānāni sotukāmo evāhaṁ bhavantaṁ kassapaṁ paccanīkaṁ kātabbaṁ amaññissaṁ.
root_text.dn23:30.3: Abhikkantaṁ, bho kassapa, abhikkantaṁ, bho kassapa.
root_text.dn23:30.4: Seyyathāpi, bho kassapa, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā kassapena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.dn23:30.5: Esāhaṁ, bho kassapa, taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi, dhammañca, bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.dn23:30.6: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ kassapo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gataṁ.
root_text.dn23:30.7: Icchāmi cāhaṁ, bho kassapa, mahāyaññaṁ yajituṁ, anusāsatu maṁ bhavaṁ kassapo, yaṁ mamassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
root_text.dn23:31.1: “Yathārūpe kho, rājañña, yaññe gāvo vā haññanti ajeḷakā vā haññanti, kukkuṭasūkarā vā haññanti, vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti micchādiṭṭhī micchāsaṅkappā micchāvācā micchākammantā micchāājīvā micchāvāyāmā micchāsatī micchāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṁso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
root_text.dn23:31.2: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, kassako bījanaṅgalaṁ ādāya vanaṁ paviseyya.
root_text.dn23:31.3: So tattha dukkhette dubbhūme avihatakhāṇukaṇṭake bījāni patiṭṭhāpeyya khaṇḍāni pūtīni vātātapahatāni asāradāni asukhasayitāni.
root_text.dn23:31.4: Devo ca na kālena kālaṁ sammādhāraṁ anuppaveccheyya.
root_text.dn23:31.5: Api nu tāni bījāni vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjeyyuṁ, kassako vā vipulaṁ phalaṁ adhigaccheyyā”ti?
root_text.dn23:31.7: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yathārūpe yaññe gāvo vā haññanti, ajeḷakā vā haññanti, kukkuṭasūkarā vā haññanti, vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti micchādiṭṭhī micchāsaṅkappā micchāvācā micchākammantā micchāājīvā micchāvāyāmā micchāsatī micchāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño na mahapphalo hoti na mahānisaṁso na mahājutiko na mahāvipphāro.
root_text.dn23:31.8: Yathārūpe ca kho, rājañña, yaññe neva gāvo haññanti, na ajeḷakā haññanti, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññanti, na vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti sammādiṭṭhī sammāsaṅkappā sammāvācā sammākammantā sammāājīvā sammāvāyāmā sammāsatī sammāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṁso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
root_text.dn23:31.9: Seyyathāpi, rājañña, kassako bījanaṅgalaṁ ādāya vanaṁ paviseyya.
root_text.dn23:31.10: So tattha sukhette subhūme suvihatakhāṇukaṇṭake bījāni patiṭṭhapeyya akhaṇḍāni apūtīni avātātapahatāni sāradāni sukhasayitāni.
root_text.dn23:31.11: Devo ca kālena kālaṁ sammādhāraṁ anuppaveccheyya.

root_text.dn23:31.14: “Evameva kho, rājañña, yathārūpe yaññe neva gāvo haññanti, na ajeḷakā haññanti, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññanti, na vividhā vā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjanti, paṭiggāhakā ca honti sammādiṭṭhī sammāsaṅkappā sammāvācā sammākammantā sammāājīvā sammāvāyāmā sammāsatī sammāsamādhī, evarūpo kho, rājañña, yañño mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṁso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro”ti.
root_text.dn23:32.1: Atha kho pāyāsi rājañño dānaṁ paṭṭhapesi samaṇabrāhmaṇakapaṇaddhikavaṇibbakayācakānaṁ.

root_text.dn23:32.15: Nanu mayaṁ, tāta uttara, puññatthikā dānasseva phalaṁ pāṭikaṅkhino”ti?
root_text.dn23:32.16: “Bhoto kho dāne evarūpaṁ bhojanaṁ dīyati kaṇājakaṁ bilaṅgadutiyaṁ, yaṁ bhavaṁ pādāpi na iccheyya samphusituṁ, kuto bhuñjituṁ, dhorakāni ca vatthāni guḷavālakāni, yāni bhavaṁ pādāpi na iccheyya samphusituṁ, kuto paridahituṁ.
root_text.dn23:32.17: Bhavaṁ kho panamhākaṁ piyo manāpo, kathaṁ mayaṁ manāpaṁ amanāpena saṁyojemā”ti?
root_text.dn23:32.18: “Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta uttara, yādisāhaṁ bhojanaṁ bhuñjāmi, tādisaṁ bhojanaṁ paṭṭhapehi.
root_text.dn23:32.19: Yādisāni cāhaṁ vatthāni paridahāmi, tādisāni ca vatthāni paṭṭhapehī”ti.
root_text.dn23:32.20: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho uttaro māṇavo pāyāsissa rājaññassa paṭissutvā yādisaṁ bhojanaṁ pāyāsi rājañño bhuñjati, tādisaṁ bhojanaṁ paṭṭhapesi.

translation_text.dn23:29.12: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our loads of hemp, and both take a load of hemp thread and go on.’
translation_text.dn23:29.13: ‘I’ve already carried this load of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’
translation_text.dn23:29.14: So one friend abandoned their load of hemp and picked up a load of hemp thread.
translation_text.dn23:29.15: They went to another deserted village.
translation_text.dn23:29.16: There they saw much sunn hemp cloth abandoned. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,
translation_text.dn23:29.17: ‘This pile of abandoned sunn hemp cloth is just what we wanted the hemp and hemp thread for!
translation_text.dn23:29.18: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our loads, and both take a load of hemp cloth and go on.’
translation_text.dn23:29.19: ‘I’ve already carried this load of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’
translation_text.dn23:29.20: So one friend abandoned their load of hemp thread and picked up a load of hemp cloth.
translation_text.dn23:29.21: They went to another deserted village.
translation_text.dn23:29.22: There they saw a pile of flax, and by turn,
translation_text.dn23:29.33: and gold abandoned. Seeing it, one friend said to the other,
translation_text.dn23:29.34: ‘This pile of gold is just what we wanted all those other things for!
translation_text.dn23:29.35: Well then, my friend, let’s abandon our loads, and both take a load of gold and go on.’
translation_text.dn23:29.36: ‘I’ve already carried this load of hemp a long way, and it’s well tied up. It’s good enough for me, you understand.’
translation_text.dn23:29.37: So one friend abandoned their load of silver and picked up a load of gold.
translation_text.dn23:29.38: Then they returned to their own village.
translation_text.dn23:29.39: When one friend returned with a load of sunn hemp, they didn’t please their parents, their partners and children, or their friends and colleagues. And they got no pleasure and happiness on that account.
translation_text.dn23:29.40: But when the other friend returned with a load of gold, they pleased their parents, their partners and children, and their friends and colleagues. And they got much pleasure and happiness on that account.
translation_text.dn23:29.41: In the same way, chieftain, you seem like the hemp-carrier in the simile.
translation_text.dn23:29.42: Let go of this harmful misconception, chieftain, let go of it!
translation_text.dn23:29.43: Don’t create lasting harm and suffering for yourself!”
translation_text.dn23:30.1: “I was delighted and satisfied with your very first simile, worthy Kassapa!
translation_text.dn23:30.2: Nevertheless, I wanted to hear your various solutions to the problem, so I thought I’d oppose you in this way.
translation_text.dn23:30.4: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Kassapa has made the teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn23:30.5: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn23:30.6: From this day forth, may the worthy Kassapa remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
translation_text.dn23:30.7: Worthy Kassapa, I wish to perform a great sacrifice. Please instruct me so it will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
translation_text.dn23:31.1: “Chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are slaughtered. And the recipients have wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion. That kind of sacrifice is not very fruitful or beneficial or dazzling or bountiful.
translation_text.dn23:31.2: Suppose a farmer was to enter a wood taking seed and plough.
translation_text.dn23:31.3: And on that barren field, that barren ground, with uncleared stumps he sowed seeds that were broken, spoiled, weather-damaged, infertile, and ill kept.
translation_text.dn23:31.4: And the heavens don’t provide enough rain when needed.
translation_text.dn23:31.5: Would those seeds grow, increase, and mature, and would the farmer get abundant fruit?”
translation_text.dn23:31.7: “In the same way, chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are slaughtered. And the recipients have wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion. That kind of sacrifice is not very fruitful or beneficial or dazzling or bountiful.
translation_text.dn23:31.8: But take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are not slaughtered. And the recipients have right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. That kind of sacrifice is very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.
translation_text.dn23:31.9: Suppose a farmer was to enter a wood taking seed and plough.
translation_text.dn23:31.10: And on that fertile field, that fertile ground, with well-cleared stumps he sowed seeds that were intact, unspoiled, not weather-damaged, fertile, and well kept.
translation_text.dn23:31.11: And the heavens provide plenty of rain when needed.
translation_text.dn23:31.12: Would those seeds grow, increase, and mature, and would the farmer get abundant fruit?”
translation_text.dn23:31.14: “In the same way, chieftain, take the kind of sacrifice where cattle, goats and sheep, chickens and pigs, and various kinds of creatures are not slaughtered. And the recipients have right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion. That kind of sacrifice is very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.”
translation_text.dn23:32.1: Then the chieftain Pāyāsi set up an offering for ascetics and brahmins, for paupers, vagrants, supplicants, and beggars.
translation_text.dn23:32.2: At that offering such food as rough gruel with false black pepper was given, and rough clothes with knotted fringes.
translation_text.dn23:32.3: Now, it was a student named Uttara who organized that offering.
translation_text.dn23:32.4: When the offering was over he referred to it like this,
translation_text.dn23:32.5: “Through this offering may I be together with the chieftain Pāyāsi in this world, but not in the next.”
translation_text.dn23:32.9: so he summoned Uttara and said,
translation_text.dn23:32.10: “Is it really true, dear Uttara, that you referred to the offering in this way?”
translation_text.dn23:32.15: Don’t we who seek merit expect some result from the offering?”
translation_text.dn23:32.16: “At your offering such food as rough gruel with false black pepper was given, which you wouldn’t even want to touch with your foot, much less eat. And also rough clothes with knotted fringes, which you also wouldn’t want to touch with your foot, much less wear.
translation_text.dn23:32.17: Sir, you’re dear and beloved to me. But how can I reconcile one so dear with something so disagreeable?”
translation_text.dn23:32.18: “Well then, dear Uttara, set up an offering with the same kind of food that I eat,
translation_text.dn23:32.19: and the same kind of clothes that I wear.”
translation_text.dn23:32.20: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Uttara, and did so.
translation_text.dn23:32.22: So the chieftain Pāyāsi gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with his own hands, giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the four great kings, in an empty palace of sirisa wood.
translation_text.dn23:32.23: But the student Uttara who organized the offering gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the thirty-three.
translation_text.dn23:33.1: Now at that time Venerable Gavampati would often go to that empty sirisa palace for the day’s meditation.
translation_text.dn23:33.2: Then the godling Pāyāsi went up to him, bowed, and stood to one side. Gavampati said to him,
translation_text.dn23:33.6: there is no afterlife, no beings are reborn spontaneously, and there’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds?”
translation_text.dn23:33.7: “It’s true, sir, I did have such a view.
translation_text.dn23:33.9: But Master Kassapa the Prince dissuaded me from that harmful misconception.”
translation_text.dn23:33.10: “But the student named Uttara who organized that offering for you—where has he been reborn?”
translation_text.dn23:33.11: “Sir, Uttara gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the thirty-three.
translation_text.dn23:33.12: But I gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with my own hands, giving the dregs. When my body broke up, after death, I was reborn in company with the gods of the four great kings, in an empty sirisa palace.
translation_text.dn23:33.13: So, sir, when you’ve returned to the human realm, please announce this:
translation_text.dn23:33.14: ‘Give gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with your own hands, not giving the dregs.
translation_text.dn23:33.15: The chieftain Pāyāsi gave gifts carelessly, thoughtlessly, not with his own hands, giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the four great kings, in an empty palace of sirisa.
translation_text.dn23:33.16: But the student Uttara who organized the offering gave gifts carefully, thoughtfully, with his own hands, not giving the dregs. When his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in company with the gods of the Thirty-Three.’”
translation_text.dn23:34.1: So when Venerable Gavampati returned to the human realm he made that announcement.
